newsitem.title: TURKEY: No survivors in Russian air crash, Turk company.
newsitem.headline: No survivors in Russian air crash, Turk company.

text.p: Almost 50 people on board a Russian AN-24 passenger plane died when the aircraft crashed in southern Russia on Tuesday, an airline representative said.

"There is nobody alive," said Mustafa Seyis of the Slotur agency which represents the plane's Russian owners in Turkey. The plane was on a flight from Stavropol in Russia to Trabzon on Turkey's northeastern Black Sea coast.
"It crashed 37 minutes after take-off from Stavropol," Seyis said. He said he had spoken to officials at Stavropol airport by telephone.
He said the plane had 41 passengers and eight crew members on board, all of them Russians. Many were travelling to Trabzon for commerce in light goods.

The aircraft crashed in a forest near the town of Cherkessk, capital of the ethnic region of Karachayevo-Cherkessiya, at 10.50 a.m. (0750 GMT), a spokesman for Russia's emergency ministry said in Moscow.
He gave no reason for the crash. Russia's air safety standards have plunged since the Soviet state carrier Aeroflot was split into hundreds of smaller domestic companies during market reforms.
The government-owned Rossiiskaya Gazeta daily newspaper said earlier this week that 219 people had been killed last year in 43 air accidents in Russian air space.
